J	De Chant, T; Gallego, AH; Saornil, JV; Kelly, M				De Chant, Tim; Hernando Gallego, Ana; Velazquez Saornil, Javier; Kelly, Maggi			Urban influence on changes in linear forest edge structure	LANDSCAPE AND URBAN PLANNING			English	Article						Urban-forest edges; Edge complexity; Urbanization; Change detection; Oak woodlands	STATISTICAL SELF-SIMILARITY; DOUGLAS-FIR FORESTS; LAND-COVER CHANGE; LANDSCAPE METRICS; FRACTAL DIMENSION; HABITAT FRAGMENTATION; BRAZILIAN AMAZON; UNITED-STATES; SHADE TREES; INDEXES	Urbanization has been a significant cause of deforestation throughout the latter half of the 20th century, and given global demographic trends, the conversion of forested land to urban uses will likely continue. California has had a long history of converting forests, and urbanization has been one of the principle drivers. While many studies have examined how urbanization alters forest landscape structure at landscape or regional scales, little is known about how urban development influences linear forest edge structure at local scales where individual homeowner decisions dominate. We studied how forest edges at two California coastal oak woodlands (Pacheco Valle (PV) and China Camp (CV)) in the San Francisco Bay Area in California changed in the decades following urbanization. Using remote sensing and object-based image analysis, we isolated 20 urban-forest edges per site and quantified each edge's complexity (measured by sinuosity) for three time points at each site. Edges exhibited low sinuosity immediately following development (PV = 1.584, CC = 1.5625), but grew significantly more complex (in 2003 PV = 1.8705, CC 1.906). Linear forest edge structure at both sites, despite different development dates, showed similar and statistically significant increases in sinuosity by 2003. We attribute the initial, more linear structure to mortality and trunk or canopy damage caused by construction, while ascribing the later, more complex structure to tree recruitment, canopy expansion, and homeowner actions that influence natural processes. (C) 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. MAY 15	2010	96	1					12	18		10.1016/j.landurbplan.2010.01.006				7	Ecology; Environmental Studies; Geography; Geography, Physical; Urban Studies	Environmental Sciences & Ecology; Geography; Physical Geography; Urban Studies	598CA	WOS:000277808700002					2019-01-11	
J	Sohm, JA; Capone, DG				Sohm, Jill A.; Capone, Douglas G.			Zonal differences in phosphorus pools, turnover and deficiency across the tropical North Atlantic Ocean	GLOBAL BIOGEOCHEMICAL CYCLES			English	Article							PACIFIC SUBTROPICAL GYRE; MICROBIAL FOOD-WEB; NITROGEN-FIXATION; PHOSPHATE-UPTAKE; DISSOLVED PHOSPHORUS; NUTRIENT LIMITATION; TRICHODESMIUM SPP.; VILLEFRANCHE BAY; SARGASSO SEA; P-LIMITATION	The oceanic phosphorus (P) cycle is often overlooked in biogeochemical studies because it is dominated by geological processes. However, recent reports indicate that some oceanic regimes are P limited; thus an evaluation of the P pools and the biological cycling of P is warranted in these locations. The subtropical and tropical North Atlantic is one area proposed to be P deficient. A cruise across a wide swath of the tropical North Atlantic (similar to 25-60 degrees W and 0-15 degrees N) allowed us to investigate spatial differences in these parameters, including in waters influenced by the Amazon River plume. The majority of the total P pool was present as dissolved organic phosphorus (DOP, similar to 80%), with soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) and particulate organic phosphorus (POP) comprising much smaller fractions. Concentrations of both SRP and POP were elevated in areas influenced by the Amazon River, while DOP was not. The turnover time of the PO(4)(3-) pool was more rapid on the western side of the basin (< 10 h) and slower to the east (> 100 h). Fast turnover times are indicative of P deficiency, and the observed trend suggests an east to west increase in P deficiency in the tropical North Atlantic. The maximal PO(4)(3-) uptake rate (V(max)) of Trichodesmium spp., a well-studied nitrogen-fixing cyanobacterium, also indicates higher P deficiency in the western compared to eastern basin. These data support the hypothesis that P could be an important nutrient limiting certain biological processes in the North Atlantic, although it may be spatially (as well as temporally) variable in this basin.	[Sohm, Jill A.; Capone, Douglas G.] Univ So Calif, Dept Biol Sci, Los Angeles, CA 90089 USA; [Sohm, Jill A.; Capone, Douglas G.] Univ So Calif, Wrigley Inst Environm Studies, Los Angeles, CA 90089 USA	Sohm, JA (reprint author), Univ So Calif, Dept Biol Sci, Los Angeles, CA 90089 USA.	sohm@usc.edu			NSF [OCE 0452765]; Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation	We would like to express our thanks to Joseph Montoya and Jon Zehr for providing support and ship time and to Ian Hewson for logistical support. We would also like to thank the captain and crew of the R/V Seward Johnson. Angela Knapp provided stimulating discussion and advice on this manuscript.
